To N Kendall
Marietta Sept 15th 1850
Dear Brother N, 
How much I wish I could be 
with you at this time! it is a delightful Sabbath morning 
the sun is shining brightly and scarcely a cloud bedims 
the face of the heavens; the church bells have just done 
ringing and all nature animate and inanimate seems 
quiet everything in keeping with this holy day of rest. I 
love to have Sabbath come--yes I believe I do more and 
more, this season is such a feast to the soul; it is at this 
time especially that-- we can lay aside all worldly cares 
and occupations and turn our thoughts upward to 
the Author of all good. Upon the Sabbath we can converse 
with our own hearts, cultivate and elevate our religious na-
tures and commune with our Heavenly Father more 
particularly than at other times and how much such 
communion strengthens us to bear the duties and trials 
of life. I feel (and may I ever feel thus) that nothing earthly 
can induce me to give up my religious enjoyment, my 
hope and faith in immortality and Heaven; it is a happiness 
too pure, too real and lasting to exchange for earths gains and 
pleasures and if the trials and sorrows which I have had to 
encounter in my short life have led me to look upon exis-
tence in anything of its true light, have weaned my affections 
from things of earth and taught me to place my trust 
and confidence in "Him who doeth all things well "glory 
honor and praise be to Him who hath called me to endure

them, although some of them have been so hard to bear. 
Sabbath here as you learned is very different from what 
it is in Kentucky, yet there I had many happy and I trust 
profitable hours alone in my room, or with you during this 
day but we could not enjoy the meetings as a general thing 
could we? Mr Weaver has commenced to day a series of sermons 
upon the parables of the New Testament, also a series of lectures 
to the young both of which are to be continued through the 
Autumn. Notwithstanding society and things of this nature 
are more congenial to my feelings here than in Mt Washington 
yet I would rather be there with you; there are many little things 
in regard to which I should be happier were I with you. I 
should feel more independent in all respects and should 
have some one in whom I could place the utmost confidence; 
now I must keep every little thing to myself for I can never open 
my heart to Brother R -- without reserve and converse with 
him of all my feelings and whatever concerns me and Brother 
Jesse you know is young and takes no interest in many things 
that interest me yet he is improving in a good many things, 
he goes to church with me, waits upon me in and sits with 
me; it was hard for him to do it at first but now he seems 
to like it very much and is ready to go with me anywhere 
I wish and I think seems more interested in his duties 
than he has done. I hope and pray he may yet be all we would 
have him; he is taking lessons in Drawing; he wished to and so 
I thought it is best he should; he has a good taste for it I think. 
Our school is prospering well and generally speaking I am pleased 
with it, however there are several little things connected with it 
that do not exactly please me. We number one hundred and

ten, fifty of whom are girls and there are but five or six of
them that do not study the larger and kind of Arithmetic, Geography 
and Grammar so that if my patrons are punctual in 
paying and succeed in pleasing them, I shall do very well in 
pecuring point of view. I have almost every kind of study 
in my department some very good scholars and some 
poor ones, particularly in mathematics, the same as I used 
to have in Kentucky; have seen in French (all beginners, 
presume shall have more) and four in Drawing and Painting; 
expect more in this class too. Chemistry I am teaching. Am 
in school from seven o'clock in the morning with half past 
five at night or rather in the afternoon when we have 
supper often which I have been the recitations of one of the young 
ladies in my room for the sake of having her remain here, 
she is diffident and has an impediment in her speech 
and does not like to go into the schoolroom to recite, has 
been away to a good many schools but would never stay more 
than a week so we want to keep her; she has been very homesick 
but think she will stay; she takes a great liking to me so she 
says-- So you see I am as busy as ever; all the time I have to devote 
to music, writing &c is a little while in the evening unless I sit 
up at night which I expect I shall be compelled to do if I attend 
to these things for I am determined to get along in school with
out assistance if possible. Helen has charge of the primary de-
partment which consists of twenty eight most of which are boys. 
There are thirty one in our family; the house is full enough and 
there is enough to be done I can assure you. Abby has sixteen 
in Music I think including Helen and myself. The Academy 
has been papered throughout since you were here and great improve-

ment has been made upon the grounds around it. I was so glad to 
see all my things and books, they seemed like old friends 
to me. I could not realize that they or myself were here and 
when I unpacked them and found how nicely everything was 
put up and thought of you there alone I ad to shed a few 
tears and almost wished myself in Kentucky with you. 
Mrs. Birch has been so kind to me since I came away as 
well as while there; have had several little tokens of affection 
from her in the form of billets beside a good long, kind 
letter since you left - a thousand thanks to her. I love her 
and Mr Birch too and my heart swells with gratitude 
towards them for their kindness and sympathy to us all. 
Tell Mrs. B. she shall have a long letter from me very soon;
would send one with this but they are waiting to carry it to 
the office. Received Lillie's letter last night (tonight is Saturday 
it is a week since I begun this scrawl) was indeed glad to get 
it but it made my heart ache to think she was sad and her 
health so poor; am afraid  remaining there will entirely destroy 
it - has she written you anything about returning to Mt. W? 
Am sorry your school is so small; write me all about it, who 
of the scholars are with you, how Achsah succeeds and likes 
&c &c cannot not bear to have the school go down how I want 
to see you all there - how do you spend your time? Are you not 
lonely? Give my love to all the scholars and tell them I should 
like to hear from them - How were they pleased with what I 
wrote them My love to Mr. and Mrs. Wright and family, Dr. Hobbs 
and family, Mrs. Kellar and all other friends. All here join 
in sending much love and many kind wishes to you and 
Achsah. Write me very often won't you for I love to hear from you. 
Affectionately Sister Sarah
Brother Raymond has gone away to day to preach and Abby and little Sarah have gone 
with him. We all went up to Mr. Barker's and spent a night before school commenced 
am looking for a letter from sister every day; Suppose it will go to you first--was glad to 
get those for my trunks.

Have you had a letter from Edwin recently? -would
like to know where to direct a letter to Erasmus.
My love to Achsah & Mrs. Wright and [illegible]
We are glad Achsah is getting along well
Have you Lillie's piano yet? Sister Sarah
Sabbath Sept 29th 
[Sarah] [ca. 1850]
My dear Brother N - 
As I was writing 
Mrs. Birch, I thought I must
send you a few lines too - Suppose 
you received my long letter several
day ago and shall look for one
from you this week and shall be 
glad enough to get it for your 
letters do me so much good now 
I cannot see you, and talk with 
you. During the past week I have 
received sister's letter and one from 
Ellen Kellar and Helen has had

one from her brother and Achsah 
and Mr. Weaver one from you 
so we have had quite a feast of 
good things in the letter line
of late - Tell Ellen she has my 
warmest thanks for her kind 
letter, and it shall be answered 
ere long - Where are all the girls that 
boarded with Mrs. Kellar last session 
that they are not in school? Am
sorry your school is so small; expected 
it - it seems John Williams is still 
with you - are Julia Swearingen, Roena 
Kinnison, &c &c? Remember me

kindly to all the scholars and all our 
friends among you. It is strange enough 
you do not hear from Miss Weed 
in regard to what you have written 
her - am afraid if she remains where 
she is her health will be entirely destroyed. 
Write me about Mr. Rice and wife 
Oh! I want that register so much -
Is there no way in which I can get 
it? It seems to me I must have 
it so as to paint one for Mother and 
Mrs. Miller. You remember those long
equations in Bourdon do you not which 
you worked out - well I can find but 
two of them among my papers, the 7th & 
8th you got them of me one day and I think 
they are among your things - look and see

Did you visit Mrs. Williams and Miss Rezaugh as you returned 
to Mt. Washington?

if you please and send them to me 
soon - if you have them not if you 
have time will you please work them 
for me for I have a class in Bourdon. 
We are all well here and I am getting to 
enjoy my school better than I have done
but I do not just like boarding with so 
many of the scholars but I must do the 
best I can while here. Often think of you there.

Mr. Nathan Kendall
Present

Marietta, Ohio, Jan 12th 1851
My own dear Brother
It is quite a long time since I 
received your last affectionate letter, and you closed it 
by requesting me to answer it soon, but your request 
has been disregarded, has it not? Well, dear Brother, 
you must pardon my delay and seeming neglect
for you know not what I have to prevent me from 
attending to my correspondents as regularly and punc-
tually as I wish. You have however undoubtedly heard from 
me several times since your last for I have sent you 
a note and written to Mrs. Wright and several of the school
girls among you in the meantime. You write that you 
long for the time to come when you shall leave Mount
Washington. I do not wonder for I know you must 
have been and still are very lonely there since I left and 
that your school during the past Autumn and this 
winter has been far from what you would have it and 
far from what it was when we were there together. It is 
hard enough to have the care and instruction of so 
many students when everything goes to suit us, when 
all in school and out, all in the society around us
pleasant and agreeable but doubly hard when almost 
everything with which we are connected is [illegible]
to our feelings. I have thought of you a great deal and
the unpleasant situation in which you have been placed 
this session and it has been a hard task for me at [illegible]

to suppress my naughty feelings when contemplating 
the manner in which you have been treated in regard
to your school, the unreasonableness of the proceedings 
which, compelled me as it were to remain here and 
leave you to get along the best way you could; it has 
always seemed so selfish to me in all connected with it; wish 
I could look upon it otherwise. I would that we might 
have remained in Mt. Washington our anticipated 
time and left with honor to ourselves (by this I do not
mean that I left without it or that you will) and returned 
home feeling fully that we had accomplished our two-
fold object in going there viz to aid ourselves in pecuniary 
point of view &c and to instruct and improve the young 
the latter I feel we have succeeded in. Some thing within 
tells me the many instructions I gave those under my 
charge there, the influence I exerted upon them, shall 
tell for good upon their future lives both here and hereafter
Oh! is it not happiness enough for this would dear Brother
to feel and know that we are being useful to those around 
us, intellectually and morally, doing their very souls good
to see those under our influence growing and expanding 
in knowledge and virtue, preparing themselves for useful-
ness and happiness in this world and for an eternity of
bliss beyond the tomb? I often think of all those who have 
come under my instructions, particularly for the last four 
years - may Heaven grant that my labors may be the means
of bringing them stores of happiness, of making them better men
and women in every sense of the word. What a source of joy 
and comfort it is to feel conscious that we are doing our duty

with this consolation we can bear with all the trials and
[illegible] of life. Never could I have borne as I did the 
first year I spent in Kentucky, knowing as I did from 
time to time the bad state of William's health had it not 
been for this conviction and the sustaining power of hope. 
I have often wondered since that I was happy at all during 
that period yet I was comparatively, although at times
no one but myself knows what were my feelings, partic-
ularly after I fully realized how low he was, and then too 
I had to bear them all alone, without sympathy as it 
were for I felt for certain reasons that I must keep my
feelings buried in the depth of my heart, but it is all passed
now and it has done my soul good therefore God be praised
though severe was the chastening rod. My love for William 
and his death have purified and increased my love and
affection for my family, friends, for all mankind, for my 
Father above - though short was his life he lived not in 
vain for through his instrumentality one soul at 
last has been exalted, purified, made better, and more
truly happy and my only desire now is to render my Mother
Brothers and Sister more comfortable and happy and 
make myself useful to the world, to all those who shall come
within the sphere of my influence. Although, at times, I feel 
sad and lonely and have anxious fears and thoughts in regards
to the future welfare of the members of my own family, especially Mother, and Jesse
Oh - whatever may be the trials in store for me I have such 
fount of peace and happiness within that it seems to me
can never be wholly miserable or feel entirely alone- 
Oh! how much I should love to talk with you - it seems to me

Don't forget to take down those curtains in the Academy and bring with you for
I can find use for them, also be sure and get that register pattern and some Theorem
[illegible] of Mrs. Rice for I feel as though I cannot give up having it. Do you see Mr. and Mrs. Rice
often? Do you know who are to take our places in the school in Mt Washington?

I could unburden my very soul to you upon every subject
much more freely than I ever have done notwith-
standing we have always been each other's confidants.
I have so many things I wish to talk with you about, some
things about which I wish your opinion and advice. 
Suppose you will be among us before many weeks and I
shall have my wishes gratified. You will dislike to leave
there on some accounts will you not? Wish I could
come there and make a visit and leave with you. 
Teachers cannot but become attached to the place where is 
the field of his labors and to those with whom he labors.
Raymond has written to you I suppose in regard to coming
here and going into the school with him. I shall not express 
to you my opinion on this subject until I see you but
I do hope you will do in regard to it as your feelings dictate
as you think best and not be urged out of the course you 
have marked out for yourself by any one. I am very anxious
to see you settled in life for I think it will be better for you and
that you will be happier. Had a letter from Sister a few days
ago (this is Saturday morn Jun 18th) stating that she was far from 
being well - her health is in rather a singular condition; feel
very anxious about her; probably she has written you in regards
to it. Received one also from Brother David last night and
it did me much good there was such a good spirit 
[illegible] throughout it and he has improved so much in his style
of writing - one too from Agnes Givens. Mother and Myron are 
well they wrote me not long ago. Have received a letter from 
[name illegible] recently and replied to it; hope she will leave there in the
spring her health is so miserable. Wasn't I happy when Mrs. Birch wrote me
that her husband had visited her? I know it did her very soul good to see his face.
[Illegible] and all her family and tell her I received her letter with pleasure. [Illegible]
[Illegible] the scholars and write immediately if you can. I commenced this [illegible]
[Illegible] was interrupted after having written a few lines and have not been able to finish [illegible]
[Illegible] now - So goes my letter writing.
All send love. My love to Achsah.
Helen says she thinks she shall write her tomorrow.

My dear Brother, 
Jesse has just brought me a letter
from you and although it is after nine o'cock for tonight
I feel that I must scribble you some what in regards to 
my feelings upon matters and things about which you 
have written to me and Brother Raymond &c &c - 
In the first place let me tell you I am alone tonight
and somewhat indisposed or recovering from a slight
indisposition. Have not felt very well at times for several 
weeks and last Wednesday morning while in school I was
seized with a very severe headache and sickness of stomach
so that I was obliged to come home and take my bed.
Was not relieved from vomiting until middle of the
afternoon; then had considerable fever all the evening 
but was well attended to so that it was brought down 
and Friday afternoon (yesterday) was able to go in to the 
Rhetorical Exercises and tonight I feel pretty well
though not quite right yet. I wish I could see you
for I could tell you my feelings so much better than 
I can write them. Raymond received your letter
the first of this week and the news it contained in regard 
to Erasmus filled me with horror - Engaged in the 
wholesale and retail liquor business! Can it be? He who
has seen a Father's noble faculties and powers destroyed,
all the better and holier feelings of his nature debased, his
usefulness frustrated, his life made dishonored and 
Sabbath - Raymond preached this morning, had a good discourse. Have been
reading Channing's discourse upon the death of Dr. Follen in which he argues sufferings and
trials are right and a part of the Divine plan and forever good - read it, My love to Erasmus
and family
Write me if you
can before coming
here. This scribbling
you must excuse
for it has been written
in the greatest
haste you know
I can write better. 
Sarah
Perhaps I should not have written you so much as I have
for I know you never would have thought for a moment of complying
with Erasmus' request had you [illegible] been discouraged in money matters
but when you consider the money you would get by this means a great
portion of it would be the hard earnings of worse than widows
and orphans I know you will not do it - you are a son of
mankind in this respect. It seems to me I cannot
have Erasmus in the business. Raymond would write
you but as I have said he will not now as he has other
letters to prepare for the office.

himself brought to a premature grave by the accursed
poison, he who has seen a Mother, Brothers, and Sisters brought 
to poverty, privation, and neglect, who has seen them 
pass days and years in agony and suffering, he who has seen
Mother suffer as our dear Mother has, sufferings and trials of which
none but herself can know the depth
and acuteness, all her bright and sunny hopes blasted 
in the buck, all her youthful expectations cut down in 
the morning of life, all the holier, purer, and more
refined feelings of her nature disregarded, her station 
in society lowered, herself shammed by the cold, un-
charitable world and she in her old age doomed
to labor, trial, and anxiety and all this brought about
by the demon Alcohol can he I say who has seen all this
and knows it is true can he touch, taste, handle or
even look with any degree complacency at all upon
the deadly monster? Much more traffic in it, deal 
it out to poor humanity when he can but know
the sin and misery it is occasioning? Am I writing
too severely Brother? Oh! but you know not with what
painful feelings it fills my heart to think of my own dear
Brother, a Brother who has ever been so conscientious in 
his doings and dealings, who has given us so many words 
of good advice, whom I have respectedly heard say that
his greatest objection to the mercantile business was
that he thought it too much of a cheating and story-
telling business, too injurious to the moral and religious
feelings of our nature is engaged, in such a death dealing
business and all for the sake of gold, for the sake of 

So then do not rob yourself for others. I wish Raymond had more prudence
in money matters but I don't know as he ever will have; he is [illegible] generous in everything
of this [illegible] and too willing to call upon others for aid. Have [illegible].
Would be better not to aid him but he is so ready to help others. I hope you will put him
up to collecting his [illegible]. Come as soon as possible and let us talk together and see what
is best for you to do - Have a great deal to tell you but can write no more now.

filling his coffers with money. Sooner would I starve or
beg from door to door and see my near and dear friends
at the same than support myself and them by wicked means, 
by bringing misery and want upon others, by encouraging 
vice and crime in the world. Let us not be over-anxious
to get-rich, there are ways enough by which we can obtain
a good and comfortable living in the world if we will 
persevere and at the same time discharge our duties 
faithfully to our fellow men and to God and feel
justified by our own consciences and by the laws of our Creator
I do not see how any one can engage in such a thing
in the slightest degree who has a single philanthropic feeling
in his breast, any real sympathy for suffering humanity, 
any desire to reform the world to [illegible] the condition
of mankind and Brother have you not all these feelings? I have
ever looked upon you as the very [illegible] of goodness, as
a christian, and you know not how it shocked me when I 
read in your letter than you might possibly go in with
Erasmus for the sake of making a little money. I believe
not that money made in direct opposition to what you know
and feel is right would prosper in your hands and I do not
believe Erasmus will prosper eventually in such a business; if
he does in this world's goods he will not spiritually nor in 
the eyes and opinions of the good. The loss which he is about 
to sustain (or which he thinks he shall) may be one of the rewards of his
occupation - Oh! how I wish I could see him and unbosom
my feelings to him, tell him kindly all I feel. You speak of aiding
Mother - I know it would be a source of acute grief to her to know 
that any of her children were helping her with money they obtained

in such a way. Leave Mother to me - let me spend my earnings
upon her and my younger brothers - will be a pleasure to me
to do it - and I need them not so much as my Brothers 
need theirs. I will attend to her house rent - Brother Raymond
and myself sent her ten dollars the first of the Winter and not
long since as we had an opportunity sent her a box of 
things consisting of groceries, about twenty-weight of butter
of Abby's make, a new dress, pair of shoes, &c - thought they 
would please her more coming from us so far away than 
the money and they were more easily obtained. Help
Edasmus all you can but I cannot for one moment
bear the thought of your going in with him and I hope he 
will see the time when he will feel it best to leave the business
you have had a hard time in pecuniary point of view and
so have we all but you must not allow yourself to be
discouraged or overcome by circumstances - truth in Him 
who ordereth all things well. How I would like to talk to 
you; believe I could make you feel better. Whom I look to
the future and see how many of my family need my aid
and how little I have with which to assist them, I feel like
giving up but I know 'tis wrong to despond or distrust providence
You have had a great deal this fall and winter to dis-
hearten you and when I tell you what I have had you will
say I have had a little too but let us come off conquerous, let
us look on the bright side of life, let us hope on, hope ever. I do 
not wish you to pay me what you won me now for I don't
need it; keep it if it will do you any good 'till I do. Jesse is
doing better, more as I wish to have him and this cheers my 
heart; his school this winter has taught him a good lesson.

Our quarter closes the 19th Get along in my school as well as ever. Mr Weaver has gone to
Wheeling and Cincinnati - more of him when you come. Remember me to all my pupils
and friends in Mt. Washington - Have not room to mention them separately
Love to Achsah. Expect to hear from Lillie soon. Come soon. Affectionately, Sister Sarah 
All send love

[Illegible Place], May 4th, 1852
Dear Brother, I have heard nothing from Mr. Weaver as yet and may
not for some time as I have not written him for so long so I know
no more about what to do in regard to going to Marietta than when I
last saw you; however I have come to the conclusion to write you that
if you feel like going there yourself and think it the best thing you can
do I will go too and stay at least two terms or a year & perhaps as long as 
you wish me. In the meantime Lydia or Josephine could become
well fitted to take my place if I should desire to leave as soon. I like 
Marietta and do not wish to lose so good an opportunity of teaching
particularly if it should become necessary for me to do so in the fall.
I do not feel that there is any certainty that I shall ever marry Mr.
W___. I shall not do so at least until I feel properly towards him for
such a union and until he is permanently located in his profession,
and this may  not be in the Autumn, but if it should be we could 
postpone our marriage till a convenient time. I think as things are it will
be wisest for me to improve the opportunity of going to Marietta if you go
and I would like to have my son with us & I will bear his expenses and 
have thought if we go there perhaps it would be best for Lydia to go to school
somewhere here two or three terms where she can have good instruction in the
Ornamentals Branches and I will assist her in money matters. I have com-
menced a letter to Mr Weaver and shall tell him what I have written you 
and also once more that the matter between us must be decided one way
or the other soon and not be kept as it has been or I can have no more to say or
do with him upon the subject and be to him only a mere acquaintance. Write me
what you think of all this and what you write to Dr. Reigner. While at
Boston please get sister and myself each a writing portfolio and me some
paint for Mezzotint painting; the color is black and the mixture I think
comes in cups or saucers also a cake or saucer of Carmine. We seem to be
pleasantly situated in our schools though we can hardly tell about them yet.
Lydia has little ones enough to look after, I assure you. You need not say to 
Dr. Regnier that I may not stay longer than I have mentioned here here for 
I may. My love to Mr. White's family and all friends. Write soon. Good bye 
Sister Sarah
If you shop at Boston long wish you would send our things up if you can
by: Express or some way if you do not go please have Franklin Brown procure them
It is fine weather this week

St. Louis, April 20th / 53
Dear Brother Nathan,
We have to day returned from
Galesburg; found your letter awaiting us, have perused 
it and now hasten not only according to request 
but according also to inclination to answer it.
We started to visit Raymond and Abby on the 11th, 
reached there on the 14th & remained until the 18th.
Achsah returned from visiting them just before we
started. We found Abby very feeble, a mere skeleton, a 
living corpse (if I may use the expression) but just as
quiet, amiable, patient and uncomplaining as ever.
You would hardly know her she is so changed. I could
not control my feelings when I met her and gazed
upon her although I had resolved I would do so, I found
her so unlike her former self, so unlike what she was
when I last saw her. She has not spoken aloud for
a number of weeks, is obliged to sit straight in her chair
all the day long without leaning against anything and at
night has to be bolstered up and reclines a little upon her

right side and hip; she cannot lay or recline for a 
moment upon her back or left side; her right hip
is black and blue, very sore and almost raw from
resting upon it so much. She does not suffer very
much she says except from weariness in being obliged
to sit up so much and so erect and when she has her
coughing turns. She does not raise very much from
her lungs and what she does raise is entirely differ-
ent from what father and mother raised; from 
the appearance of it it seems to me her lungs can-
not be ulcerated at all. Physicians have not been
able to tell her definitely what does aid them. I think 
her present condition has all arisen from not having
had her system regulated after the birth of little Sarah.
Nothing as regards female peculiarities has been natural
with her since that time. Why she and Raymond
should not attend to a matter of so much importance
as soon as they knew how it was I cannot understand. 
Relief certainly could have been found if sought earnestly.
How apt we all are to neglect our physical systems when 
diseased until they become past remedy then we see when

too late where we have erred! How strange it is
that we cannot learn wisdom from the past 
and from the follies and neglects of others! Hellen
devotes her whole time to Abby and little Sarah and 
takes good care of them; Raymond has no boarders
and has a girl to do the housework. Abby rides out
occasionally, walks about her room some, has 
a swing in her room in which she swings more or
less every day for exercise and variety; has a pretty 
good appetite. Her feet have been swelling for the last 
two or three weeks and the swelling is extending up her
limbs. Her neighbors and friends are very kind to her
continually sending her something and coming in 
to see her. She likes company very much, cannot
bear to be alone; we devoted our whole time while there 
to her and she seemed to enjoy it very much; wish I
was where I could go in and sit with her often; she is
aware of her condition though she says she cannot see
what there is about her lungs that cannot be cured,
says her faith is a good one to die by, has no fears, is 
ready to live or die. I wish Raymond would spend more

of his time with her and wait upon her more. 
I know the little attention he could give her would
do her more good than what anyone else could do
for her but he is with her scarcely a moment during
the day or evening, all his time is engrossed in business.
I think his wife in her feeble condition should be
the first object of his thoughts and care and his 
business he second; I know he is very much at -
tached to her and hints he does the best he can 
in the matter. The portion of Illinois through which 
we passed is a delightful region of country for agr-

Dear Aunt Abbie Kendal,

whos who- & what people are doing-
in Europe. That letter deserved an answer, 
& Jennie forgets whether she answered it 
or not.
Now we have got settled down in this nice
house & have had time to turn round,
we have more time for writing than
we had, sometimes, while we were
perpetually moving.
Incessant rain keeps us at home today.
I think of you as still at Kankakee;
though I expect to hear, soon, that you
have gone further South.
On the 22nd Ult. a downstairs fire occurred

on my Blennerhasset Farm - four
miles from this place where we live -
and destroyed property in buildings,
machinery & crop to the amount of
about 1200 -(six thousand dollars)
The fire was due to searching for an
escape of gas in the farm building
with a lighted candle & finding it!
The property was not insured.
Numbers of people were on the spot
soon after the fire broke out - it
broke out about 7:45 P.M. -
our great double 12 inch diameter
pumps used for pumping liquid manure
were got to work as soon as possible;
& there was plenty of water, but the 
fire had got a great hold in a
wonderfully short time & it raged for
several hours. Part of the buildings 
were pulled down to save the rest.
Many of the people worked admirably, 
among falling slates timber &c.
but no life was lost; & no person
seriously hurt.
I am glad we are able to bear the loss
without having to suffer anything
like poverty on account of it.

Jennie - we call her Emilie here,
though I still write to America of her
as Jennie - is reading Sir Walter Scots
"Lady of the Lake" for the first time;
& is properly delighted with it.
We usually read Shakspeare together
in the morning for about 2 or 3

great many books in prospect.
Jennie talks of recommencing to 
paint tomorrow; if she does, I mean
to read to her, while she paints.

Farming is not much a profitable
business here as we suppose it to 
be in Illinois. How are times 
with Illinois farmers now?
Here we have a terrible potato
disease. - I have about 105 acres
ie about one quarter of my farm
planted with potatoes; & about
two thirds of them are diseased, we think &
therefore unsaleable except at about a quarter

of last year's price per ton. Good potatoes
are probably worth about 50 per cent
more this here, here, than last year.
I do not know whether you & Mr Kendal

We mean to begin in earnest to harvest
potatoes as soon as the weather permits.
Some correspondence has passed between us
& James & Reed & Mary Tyler about
their education; & about them on the
27th of June this year, I wrote to Mr. Winsor
"I know of no reason why they should 
not all become highly cultivated people".
However, wiser & more experienced people
than myself are better able than I
to judge of this matter; & very
likely the good advice of some
trusted & trustworthy friend
might be more valuable to them now.
We mean to go to Edinburgh on the
6th - Trox. to stay with my sister Mrs. Hill,
& to see a Cat Show there on the 7th Trox.
yours truly
William Lawson
